reviews.title: Both versions are Great, Here are some Poke Exclusives Mentioned!
reviews.text:
I have Both! Awesome revamp to one of the greatest Pokemon Generations. Super, super fun with the same awesome graphics from X and Y and an improved story from the GBA Gen III games. If I had to pick one or the other I simply couldn't do it. Alpha Sapphire you are fighting PIRATES aka Team Aqua and Sapphire was originally the first of the 2 games I got for the GBA gen Pokes. It will always hold a special place in my heart personally. HOWEVER if you want Nuzleaf or it's evolved form, Koffing, or Zangoose I'd say go with Omega Ruby instead. Of course just me personally I prefer Alpha Sapphire's Grimer and Seviper but as far as Lombre or Nuzleaf I'd say Nuzleaf all the way. Ruby gives you Latios while Sapphire gives you Latias so they are legendary clones but one is blue and the other is red. Whatever floats your boat guys but overall I like the whole experience of Sapphire better. A final not: Kyogre from Sapphire has the type advantage over Groudon. I don't use Legendaries myself but what is more useful overall ground or water? I'll leave that up to you, just remember Water affects all types but ground does not and if a Poison type or Ghost type has levitate that is a double whammy.

CONS: They didn't bring back roller skates and you have to wait for your bike for a bit (as it was in the original R&S).

reviews.title: Best game on switch
reviews.text: 5 years old now but still has legs. Open exploration, non-linear adventure is very empowering. I have solved some of the puzzles in very unconventional ways and the game allows that. Wonderful sense of achievement and satisfaction. But sometimes I realize the simpler solution was the easiest

reviews.title: Great Headphones and perfect for Vault by Pelican Case
reviews.text: I agree with most of the reviewers… The headphones have good sound quality, plushy foam, not really snug on ears but since I don’t like things snug on my ears — bonus.  The one thing-to note is adding them to the elite strap makes them a permanent add-on since removing them is not convenient as it is a snug fit and you risk breaking the elite strap.  Finally, they no longer fit in the Oculus Quest 2 (OQ2) case and other cases for OQ2 like the Sarlar case which is bigger than most cases for OQ2.  This is a biggie for me.  I like to keep my OQ2 in a protective case when it is not being used.  Unfortunately most OQ2 case designs are compact.  So adding the elite strap, clip-on headphones, grips on controllers that add bulk, and keeping other cords, etc., finding a case is tough.  However, I found the “Vault by Pelican - v525 Case with Padded Dividers for Equipment, Electronics Gear, Camera (Black)”.  A little pricey in regard to OQ2 cases but VR headsets are expensive and it is easy to shell out lots of money for the extras so protection is important to me.

reviews.title: Honestly seems perfect.
reviews.text:
I bought this to replace a cracked screen protector of a different brand, getting that out of the way now.

An on-going issue I have with putting screen protectors onto the devices themselves is that I always seem to mess something up. Even when following instructions. I know right? I'm a dolt. :)
This, however, was no the case here. The glass came with really nifty tabs to hold onto, allowing me to easily and accurately place it on the glass. Removing remaining bubbles was easy as well with the provided tool, just remember not to press the screen down hard before removing bubbles. I'm sure you still could but it'd be a more annoying process, I speak from experience.
As for the hardness, and with it scratch resistance and overall protection, only time will tell. I can say that it felt sturdy when applying it.
It's also VERY clear, you can only tell you have one on if you look to the edges and see the difference in height. I don't notice any change in perception of color at all. Overall I definitely recommend it.

Included are two screen protectors in thin foam sleeves, warranty registration paper, two packs of wet and dry cleaning wipes, microfiber cloth, little sticky doodles to remove dust just prior installation post cleaning if some happens to be visible, scrape-y card for removing bubbles, and an installation manual.

Pros:
-Easy installation, even for installation challenged users
-Comes with two just in case you mess up or have a friend in need
-Very clear
-Warranty is easy to register

Cons:
-Can't see any as of yet. :)

reviews.title: Possibly the best of it's kind.
reviews.text:
I hate to sound like a fanboy, but the Razer Naga is the best MMO gaming mouse I've tried. I've tried alot of mice.

This will be my second Naga. My previous one wore out after over 5 years of using it more than I should have. It's only that the button under the scroll wheel wore out. I'm surprised that any mouse lasted as long as the Naga did.

The buttons take some getting used to. It took me about a year to consistently use all of the side buttons. The last row always felt kind of awkward to reach. Those are buttons I rarely use anyways.

One thing I noticed about this particular model of Naga is that my previous one had a switch that changed between the keyboard numbers and the number pad. This one has no switch and only functions off the keyboard numbers.

The mouse is a good size and the buttons are responsive. My biggest gripe with other gaming mice are that they are often oddly shaped or way too large, and are made of cheap materials.

reviews.title: Very comparable in quality to leading brands and great value

Buttons has good clickiness to it and does not feel too squishish.
Overall this is comparable to leading gaming brands but provides better value.
